body:
pull the most recent code and compile:
git pull && git submodule update && make clean && make
It was my mistake, I mixed up between versions. I by the way used the windows prebuilt libs but mixed up the sources and that was the problem. its all working as it should. thanks
I'm closing this as its resolved.

Because of the current NDArray do not support slice, so you need to convert it to numpy array to do slice, and then convert it back to NDArray, if you need two label in one list, i think can use your first post code, it's not ugly.  
the reason you use like `return mx.io.DataBatch(data=batch.data, label=batch.label, pad=batch.pad, index=batch.index)` failed, is that your loss layer do not support multi-label, so the shape is not matched.
@tornadomeet thank you very much for your explain. I would like to make clear whether mxnet default implementation loss layer can support multi-label?

@piiswrong 
it doesn't work!

Would you please try this example.

``` bash
sudo python run.py --gpu -1 --content-image input/IMG_4343.jpg --style-image input/starry_night.jpg
```

#2124

@piiswrong: can I add support for this, copying how it was done for NDArrayOpInfo/NativeOpInfo? Or do you have another preference?

@vchuravy: would adding this support be useful for the Julia port?
@sbodenstein We will probably need it for Julia, but I haven't looked into the best way of doing this with Julia v0.5.

@vchuravy: ok, then your feedback for the design will be very useful.

Here is one proposal: each function pointer takes an additional argument, the name of the op (char\* op_type). This seems simpler and more intuitive than using void pointers to do the dispatch (like the old NDArrayOpInfo used).

Thanks a lot for the contribution! We are planning to move the notebooks to a separate repo to reduce the burden of the main one. 

For now, what we can do instead is you can open a repo called mxnet-multi-task-example on your side, and we can add a link to your repo  from example. This can increase visibility of your contribution, and we can do more comments on the issues there
we can create a notebook repo and make it a sub module under example

It can be traced back to these line:

> model = mx.model.load("Inception/Inception_BN", iteration=39)
> [18:29:50] d:\chhong\mxnet\src\operator./softmax_output-inl.h:225: Softmax symbol is renamed to SoftmaxOutput. This API will be deprecated in Dec, 2015
> 
> normed <- preproc.image(im, mean.img)
>   Error: Expecting a four-dimensional array
This is due to `imager`. It changes some APIs we use.
it depends what's loss do you use, as i know, the SoftmaxOutput support multi-output(which is one of multi-label), you can check the fcn-xs examples for how to use it.

Hi @tqchen 

I move the notebooks to https://github.com/haria/mxnet-multi-task-example

the file URL is: https://github.com/haria/mxnet-multi-task-example/blob/master/multi-task.ipynb

Thanks!
sounds great, I am closing this PR. Please send another PR to add the link to your notebook in multi task example's markdown as well as example/README.md
The stated issue is due to the pre-trained Inception-BN model. Please see #2155 for the solution.

Hi @tornadomeet 

Thank you very much for your help!
I would like to know the input data shape of SoftmaxOutput after I specify "multi_output=True" 

before multi-output code likes below

``` python
    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool, name="flatten1")
    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=10, name="fc1")
    sm1 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc1, name="softmax1")
    fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=2, name="fc2")
    sm2 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc2, name="softmax2")
    softmax = mx.symbol.Group([sm1, sm2])

    return softmax
```

after multi-output added,

``` python
    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool, name="flatten1")
    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=10, name="fc1")
    fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=2, name="fc2")
    #TODO fc = fc1+fc2 ?
    softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc, name="softmax", multi_output=True)
    return softmax
```

Since the num_hidden in fc1 and fc2 are different, I don't know how to set the "data" field for the SoftmaxOutput here.

thank you very much!

Hi, I was confused with online doc about that '_' in attribute naming. Do you mean the we should not use any '_' when naming an attribute? That 'init_bias' in the example is against my assumption. So maybe you mean not the first letter?

@yech1990 You can directly submit the python script like `qsub -q gpu.q test.py` . Since MXNet requires other linking libraries, you may need to create a new bash script and initialize these environment variables at the beginning. Check the usage guidance of your GPU cluster for more information.
Also, if you want to do distributed training, you need to read the tutorial http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/multi_devices.html and try the examples in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification.

I found that I set the `batch` parameter in the `train_imagenet.py`  to 100, which is too large for my computer. After I set it to 32, it succeeds. 
So this issue could be closed.
I get the same compile error. I don't know how it occurs. Did you solve this problem?

It's very hard for people to help you without knowing what you did and where the crash happened.
If possible, always post a minimal script that reproduce your error

I solved this problem. It is a project dependency problem. Same as #1870 .
I just re-download the project with commond: git clone --recursive https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.
Copy the old config.mk to new diretory and recomplile it.

sorry to response later. I combined the commits but find its already merged. 

Thanks all.
Btw, we still need a new operator 'average pooling', otherwise the output size won't match the label size

@yech1990 
just pulled the repo, and did a clean compile in linux, run the neural example and I can confirm that there is no problems with it. I think you have different libs mixed up like i did before. Try to remove all your mxnet and recompile.

@sxjscience  thank you very much!
The GPU cluster guidance is out of date, and the administor is not willing to give any help.

Would you please show one line of example for initializing the environment variables.

BTW, do I need to declare any variable in the PBS script if I install python in my own direction without root. For the GPU cluster only has python 2.4.

@yech1990 
yes, I did:
python run.py --gpu -1

this executes the processing on the cpu - and sets all the other variables to default.

This looks to me a region detection problem task.
As the RCNN suggests, 
maybe you should divide the picture into regions, with the center of each region the coordinate you want, use CNN to extract the features, and use some other classifier, such as SVM, to find the wanted region.

Hi @zhangchen-qinyinghua 

The coordinate is not extract from image but captured from controller such as XBOX controller or PS4 dualshock.

I found solution already. Linear Regression accept N-dim input and 2-dim output, anyway, thank you all the same!

Bucket io is still very specific to each particular user application or task. That file could be used as an reference or example when writing your own io. Yes, I think at least some links in the old tutorial should be updated.
@Godricly Thanks for pointing out. This was a mistake. I am fixing it in #2159.
`git submodule update --recursive` will also do the thing.

Hi

Thanks for your advice. In fact I had to change more things in mxnet_predict-all.cc. I am using 691f1d3 as a starting point.

My method:

When I compiled jni_libmxnet_predict.so there were some undefined references. I could identify them using:

`ndk-which nm` jni_libmxnet_predict.so | grep "\sU\s" | less

Then when there was an undefined method I could pipe to c++filt -n in order to identify the missing code.

Using this method I was able to identify that most of the contents of operator_util.cc were missing from  mxnet_predict-all.cc.

I put the missing lines into mxnet_predict-all.cc. I am attaching the diff of what I changed, and my version of mxnet_predict-all.cc, as well as the compiled JNI binary. Hopefully this will help anybody who encountered the same problem.

[changes-for-android-to-mxnet_predict-all.diff.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/266292/changes-for-android-to-mxnet_predict-all.diff.txt)
[jni_libmxnet_predict.so.zip](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/266285/jni_libmxnet_predict.so.zip)
[mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/266276/mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip)

Hm how do you deal with different instance of the same operator? The reason
for using void pointer is so that the front-end can attach an arbitrary
payload.

Is there any script (from MXNet model to Caffe model) that could be shared so far? And can we convert any kind of MXNet model (e.g., GoogleNet, ResNet, or some customized model) into their Caffe format directly?
@EasonD3 I think it is better to ask this question in Caffe issue. We don't have script to convert model to caffe and and we don't have plan to do it.
I see. Thanks @antinucleon

@piiswrong I'm reluctant to describe the trick `weight_lr_mult` in details as it might get quite confusing for new users. Maybe we could add a simple tutorial for the attributes used by the optimizers without really going into details about what happens underlying (copying of attributes into automatically created variables).
cc @pluskid With this, we might be able to support module parallel module with a graph spanning two devices

@haria  yours is more like multi-task application, less like multi-label(Although it has many label for each instance), and softmax with mulit-output is not fit your problem, so you can check the multi-task example, like https://github.com/haria/mxnet-multi-task-example/blob/master/multi-task.ipynb and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/e75660f70e0e92ed8f4c48bf1f05eee597b5705f/example/multi-task

We bind groups to specific context/devices. Let's assume that I have a network that spans two devices and I want to run batches in parallel over four devices. Is this still possible or do I have to use node level parallelism to express that?

you should use larger lr(not the lr in the readme file ), because of  softmaxoutput operator has been changed from then on.  
or you can delete the line https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/softmax_output-inl.h#L108, and rebuild mxnet,then use the lr describled in the readme.
resize=64,not 12288 when using im2rec
OK. Please fix the test error and we can merge
merge this in for now, @sxjscience you are more than welcomed to contribute a better version like sum(axis=..)

@vchuravy currently this is in low level API, so not much related to what module will do.  You are talking about mixed data/model parallel program. I think what you asked for is possible, but is not supported
Let us first make the fix by adding fix_gamma=False as you suggested, so things are consistent. Can you open a PR on this? Thanks!
@tornadomeet Thanks! I am not familiar with the source code. Could you tell me grad_scale and s[3] mean in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/softmax_output-inl.h#L108.
So how can we save the optimizer states and reload them when resuming the training?
mx.io.ImageRecordIter shuffle data  within chunks

any idea what's causing this?
    return np.sum(x, keepdims=1, axis=tuple(axis))
TypeError: sum() got an unexpected keyword argument 'keepdims'

Have no idea about the problem... Let me test again.
closing this since we are moving to new one
Are you using async or sync
I used sync
How about to change the example image?https://github.com/lisabug/mxnet/blob/31c995724d971379b60f3831b47e8db52cb45a11/example/image-caption/test.jpg

@fangyizhang  the line is used for gradient normalization, s3[2] is the image label size(equals image size,and it is very large), so if we do not divide this,then the gradient will be very large(for it sums all the label), so we need small lr,like 1e-10.  
if we divide the label numbers in that line, then the gradient is normalized, so we can use normal lr, which is larger than the lr in the readme.
Follow these instructions and still can't make a working gpu mxnet on windows for R. Can you please make a step by step for us. Thanks.
@tornadomeet Thanks a lot. I delete the code, then it works.

you can have multiple of them as long as they are registered to different names.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2051/files#diff-234886ea4087927b3aadc36ec77635c4R21

this is registration of op classes. Insstances can then by created from the
class. Instances can have internal state.

wrote:

> current design seems to explicitly disallow this: there is a check in
> custom-inl.h:
> 
>   static void Register(const std::string &op_type, CustomOpPropCreator creator) {
>     if (registry_.find(op_type) != registry_.end()) {
>       LOG(WARNING) << "New registration is overriding existing custom operator " << op_type;
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2051#issuecomment-219705966

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/4537
looks like a numpy bug that's recently fixed. Has to do with masked arrays. Maybe try to copy them into normal arrays

you can't. If you want to operate on single elements convert it to numpy array and back.

Scala package is under development by @javelinjs. It's a work in progress. You are welcome to contribute to it.

of course. it should basically be mimicking native op and numpyop

Thanks first!
it's is better now, but with new question.
I noticed that the data shape is (3, 64, 64) as an example, and imshow() need(64,64,3), so I use

``` python
X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
```

you can find the output images like below
![img](https://github.com/ShawnXuan/images/blob/master/2016-05-17%2022_26_45-Figure%201.png?raw=true)

these pictures are original full color, is there any other things I was wrong or ignored? thanks!

BR
i used broadcast rather than broadcast_with_axis because i guess the former has less index operators and may have better performance,

@tqchen , thanks for the reply. Since this issue only occurs in Inception-BN during fine-tuning and some other models are also using `BatchNorm` with the default `fix_gamma=True`, changing the Inception-BN symbol file (i.e., [symbol_inception-bn.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/symbol_inception-bn.py)) may not be a good practice?

Thanks, after change the batch size to 64 or 32 which is 128 originally used for one node train, the accuracy is increased to 88% now, with 10 nodes, 8 workers, 1 dispatcher, 1 server. 
I'm confused, it that mean we need to decrease the batch size where distributed training ?
If so, is there any best practice on how to decrease the batch size or learning rate?
And still, I not so sure how much server and worker to used for better performance?
And it save model on every nodes, which to used or they are the same?

So many question, I would be grateful if you could provide any help !
@piiswrong

divide by the number of nodes would give you exactly the same result (i think @mli could you confirm?) with sync. But it may be slow. 

Hyper parameter tuning is in general messy. Do it long enough and you'll develop intuition.

the effective batch size for sync is num_node \* batch_size. as for mnist, a large minibatch size (i guess >256) affect the convergence a lot. but for large dataset, such as imagenet, it is less sensitive to the batch size.
@mli I've removed the keepdims and inplace flags. Also I've tested broadcast_mul and the code is correct.

`argmax` may not be needed for a sequence-to-sequence learning model. During training, we can use softmax + crossentropy to compute the loss. For testing, we can get the output of softmax activation and perform beam-search. 
Also, to add an `argmax` operator, you can fill in the backward implementation of the current `argmax` https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/broadcast_reduce_op-inl.h#L183 and register it as a symbol.
@sxjscience Thanks for your comment. I will try it!

Seems that small batch size have bad effect on the efficiency.
I would test with imageNet to get better comprehension of those issue.

Still have some question:
1、 "the effective batch size for sync is num_node \* batch_size", how about the effective batch size for async mode?
2、 how much server and worker to used for better performance ?
I think that the parameter server is used for release the communication  pressure of many workers' pulling and pushing to one server, but too much server would cause the sync communication to become huge, is that right? It seems that the default setting is the same number of worker and server， is that the best practice setting?
I test the same number of worker with different number of server, there isn't obvious change of the efficiency.
3、 it save model on every nodes, which to used or they are the same?
This is quite a dump question but my cluster environment is sharing one file system, and the saved model is all named the same and keep covered by the latest node model, so I can't check it myself.

@mli @piiswrong thanks a lots.

This question has an answer in issue #892 .
The input data is not a standard one-hot vector, but a vector(or matrix) contains vocabulary index.
I quaoted from @pluskid "Say if you have an input of shape (10, 20), each element is the index of the word in the vocabulary. Then the output will be of shape (10, 20, D) where D is the embedding dimension."
Where is the code doing such transform. I does not find code in embedding-inl.h
Thanks, I re-built it for win7, and it works as it should.

no such function. it used mini-batch during train, does it need to print out the tags for every image?
if you want to print, you shoud add the code in metric.py, and add A New Class to do it.
Any updates on integrating nccl to MXNet?

Hi,
a) I'm quite sure the answer is yes, you need to write the operator by yourself. [Here](http://mxnet-tqchen.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/new_op.html) you can find how to write a new layer.
b)Seems like your problem is the dataset. In the same paper there are some references to Re-ID Databases, like CUHK03, CUHK01, VIPeR

Hope it helps.
Cheers!

a) You can try to use mx. symbol.Concat mx.symbol.maximum + - \* / and [other symbol](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol.html), to implement "cross-input neighborhood difference". If it is impossible, you have to write the operator.

b) You can combine the pair of two image to one 120x160 image. If the two image is same person set the train label to 1, else set train label to 0. Then use mx.symbol.SliceChannel to slice 120x160 image to two 60x160 data, at the begin of the network.
Looks right to me.
LGTM. Could you verify that the custom_op example still works and we can merge.
LGTM. @mli Could you have a look and lets merge

Looks like it works on gpu but not cpu. I'll look into it.
